item.title:
Why can’t Russia accept Ukraine’s independence?
Our film explains. Watch here ⬇️

The origins of the crisis lie in 2014, when an uprising toppled Viktor Yanukovych, Ukraine’s then president. Since then, as Ukraine’s government turned to the West for political and military support, Vladimir Putin has grown more hostile https://t.co/QX4DbIr0xW
NATO will not fight for Ukraine. Instead America and Europe have mustered a three-pronged response https://t.co/Ip9wFM6DDa
Russia’s military build-up around the Ukraine border was detected through open-source intelligence such as images and other data from commercial satellites https://t.co/GK2fXgWIWt

Vladimir Putin has gone to war in Ukraine. President Joe Biden has promised that America and its allies would respond “in a united and decisive way”.
Catch up quickly on the latest updates ⬇️
Now that hostilities are breaking out, the most immediate question is how far Russia is prepared to go to subdue its neighbour https://t.co/8lCF3p4nLR
How bad could a modern cyberwar be, and will other countries be affected? https://t.co/4vr9CxicDP
Russia has never accepted Ukrainian independence. We explain the history of the forced brotherhood between the two countries https://t.co/1j5slnKJWZ

Invading Ukraine could ultimately prove Vladimir Putin’s undoing, we wrote in a recent article, if it turns into a bloody quagmire or makes Russians poorer, angrier and more eager for change https://t.co/TjXeUnAw7s
Last year we explained how Russia’s president had been silencing his opponents https://t.co/fjPBFHnDsi
America and its allies will respond “in a united and decisive wave”, Joe Biden says, after explosions are reported in cities around Ukraine. Follow the latest updates https://t.co/35TC6QqeBg

Russia was not threatened by NATO or Ukraine. Its invasion of the sovereign state next door is a war of choice, conjured out of nothing by Vladimir Putin. History will judge him harshly https://t.co/2xfOKB5uWh
Our coverage explains what’s at stake, what lies behind Vladimir Putin’s thinking and what might happen next https://t.co/8xbSn0h0LW

The Russian elite has long believed that the dire consequences made a war of choice unthinkable for a calculating man like the president. But, as we wrote recently, the growing prospect of war left them deeply unnerved https://t.co/gyZU7peUrW

Shortly after the declaration there were reports of explosions in Kyiv and several other cities around Ukraine, including Kharkiv, Kramatorsk, Odessa and Mariupol. There were also unconfirmed reports of firing around Kyiv airport https://t.co/nGgQcSCPX7
BREAKING: Vladimir Putin goes to war, after announcing a “special military operation” with the aim of demilitarising and “denazifying” Ukraine https://t.co/qBLMHY5FW8

If Russia invades Ukraine, there is “no doubt” that the country “should pay a significant price”, says Dmitri Alperovitch. “But immediately slapping Russia with the full range of economic penalties risks leading to a spiralling situation” https://t.co/CC0VP762xJ
Italy has one of the lowest adult obesity rates in the rich world. So why do proposed EU ratings categorise much of its food as unhealthy? https://t.co/e5tCmHauIa
An unpleasant cold-war arrangement is contemplated for Ukraine https://t.co/G5wSuBs8Ra

A wise government would listen and respond politely, taking protesters’ complaints seriously and patiently explaining why covid restrictions are necessary for the time being. Justin Trudeau has done the opposite https://t.co/h4njMHEby0
More than a third of the world’s population live under authoritarian rule while just 6.4% enjoy a full democracy https://t.co/ljmIHZ6Nt9
Humanity’s greatest political achievement has been the decline of war. That is now in jeopardy https://t.co/KIRh580rhF
The show’s creator, Steven Knight, says he wanted to offer a more nuanced depiction of the working class compared with other period dramas https://t.co/7KoTmZc7pN
It is the biggest concentration of firepower in Europe since the cold war https://t.co/BUcTeZ5HvX
They show tremendous potential in treating certain mental-health disorders https://t.co/9Cv66jIRbw

A wise government would listen and respond politely, taking protesters’ complaints seriously and patiently explaining why covid restrictions are necessary for the time being. Justin Trudeau has done the opposite https://t.co/LtJvGTGfdi

Vladimir Putin has alleged that Ukraine is committing “genocide” against Russian-speaking citizens of the Donbas. But all the evidence points to Russian-backed escalation of hostilities https://t.co/dhg8VTLW40
White power, dark money https://t.co/Y4HwGsfFTw

A wise government would listen and respond politely, taking protesters’ complaints seriously and patiently explaining why covid restrictions are necessary for the time being. Justin Trudeau has done the opposite https://t.co/hEMqyMv214
More than a third of the world’s population live under authoritarian rule while just 6.4% enjoy a full democracy https://t.co/JcxymtivHg
Most of what Russia’s president said was utter nonsense, but the implication that something terrible is soon to happen may not be https://t.co/BabMfVHYsO
It is the biggest concentration of firepower in Europe since the cold war https://t.co/5cR53y0V4C
Olaf Scholz’s decision that Nord Stream 2 should not operate is the biggest in a raft of sanctions imposed against Russia by Western countries https://t.co/BdXLDqniHz

♦️ Olaf Scholz halts the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline.
♦️ Russia’s parliament ratifies Vladimir Putin’s decrees to recognise Donetsk and Luhansk.
♦️ President Volodymyr Zelensky considers severing diplomatic ties with Russia.
Stay up to date on the crisis in Ukraine ⬇️

Olaf Scholz, Germany’s chancellor, says he will not allow Nord Stream 2 to operate. It is the biggest in a raft of sanctions imposed against Russia by Western countries. We explain why the gas pipeline is so controversial https://t.co/PljaV8F8mH
Russia’s parliament wants to formally recognise the independence of the two self-proclaimed republics https://t.co/5YpPOHNhxW
Better than you might think https://t.co/j68rJUOpVd
Humanity’s greatest political achievement has been the decline of war. That is now in jeopardy https://t.co/wH8Tl02odb
Vladimir Putin’s speech, filled with anger and resentment, provided the ideological foundations for further military action, should Russia’s president decide on it https://t.co/SAOeboUqNZ
The mayor is ready for anything https://t.co/l6Rcxifsxb

A greater reliance on China would condemn Russia to being the junior partner of an unsentimental regime which sees it as a diplomatic sidekick and a backward source of cheap commodities https://t.co/5nr2faU3uN

In a long and threatening speech Russia’s president questioned the legitimacy of Ukraine’s independence and accused NATO of using it as a base from which to threaten his country https://t.co/OtZhgOdHJJ
Shelling along the line of control has increased dramatically this month. Leaders of the breakaway regions have begun moving civilians to Russia https://t.co/96OXxooGPA
Human suffering, economic shock and a geopolitical realignment https://t.co/YrClZu2A5P

In a move that seemed to take Europe to the brink of war, Vladimir Putin officially recognised the breakaway “people’s republics” of Donetsk and Luhansk in eastern Ukraine, and said he would deploy Russian troops to them https://t.co/qd8veuYLU1
Vladimir Putin is courting disaster for Russia’s neighbour—and himself https://t.co/1FTf3mBS37
The move makes diplomacy much harder and increases the chance of war https://t.co/iNgrt4pYf1
Why do these regions matter? And how might Russian recognition of their independence alter the course of the crisis? https://t.co/bAvoPwtYub
Better than you might think https://t.co/BCDhacZDha
It is the biggest concentration of firepower in Europe since the cold war https://t.co/AVDICuI9Yw
